speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So now we're coming onto brains and consciousness and we take three statements, which I think are fairly widely believed.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: One is that consciousness is caused by events inside the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Number two is that consciousness has meanings about external things like coffee cups or the presentation or your computer screen.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the third point is that the brain is a neural computer and only a neural computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Now, these statements, I will claim, are not mutually consistent.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: One of them has to be wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The reason is, if the brain is only a neural computer, all the information inside is encoded and has no defined meaning.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So that information can't cause consciousness of things, consciousness with meanings inside.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And if you look at those three statements, the first two, I think, are empirical facts.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we can come back to discuss that later.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But most people believe that consciousness is caused by events in the brain because when brains are damaged, consciousness gets interrupted.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And you can't be conscious.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Most of the things you're conscious of are something happening in the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And it has meaning about external things.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I think those two are well-established facts.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the third is an assumption.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We're only assuming that computing is the only thing that goes on in brains.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I think three is the thing that's wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So that runs straight up against a philosophical assumption called computational functionalism.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Computational function is a thesis that forming the right kind of computations is sufficient and necessary and sufficient for consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And this is described recently as a mainstream, although disputed, position in the philosophy of mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Now, it's also called computational sufficiency.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: David Chalmers called it that in an article in 2012.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And what the results of the first half of this talk imply is that that is wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: In other words, being a computer is not sufficient to be conscious.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Now, most theories of consciousness assume computational functionalism.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They are theories in which the brain is a computer and the brain has consciousness by virtue of being a computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the implication of this viewpoint is that those theories of consciousness cannot be correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that is the main implication of this talk for theories of consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So to talk about some specific theories of consciousness, most of them assume that consciousness is caused by events of the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The brain is a complicated neural computer, the most complicated machine in the universe we see here.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And inside this computer, there are various computational processes taking place.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I call these P1, P2, and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And most theories of consciousness assume that one or other of these processes called P5 or P4 causes consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so you can look at examples of modern theories of consciousness from this viewpoint.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You might think P1 is representing things in the visual field.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Theories of consciousness like Lame, like, yeah, Lame and so on, people believe those theories.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or you might think,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: As in the free energy principle, the brain is building Bayesian models of reality, and that leads to consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or you might feel some higher order theory of consciousness that P3 is the brain reflecting on its own computations, and that causes consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or going with Antonio Damasio, you might feel that the brain is computing an emotional response to events, and that emotional response is the heart of consciousness.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or you might feel along with Bernard Bars and Dehaene and others that global workspace is what makes us conscious.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So making information globally available is a computational process.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or you might feel along with IIT that you need computations linked together with some very high connectivity, which is measure five.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or you might think that P7 is predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: All of those you're saying, some
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: computational process is what makes the brain conscious.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The point of this talk is that those processes, P1 or P2 or whatever they are, don't happen inside brains.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They happen in our interpretations of brains as computations.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But from the information actually inside a brain itself, the processes could be completely different processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They could be Q1, Q2 and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so those theories of consciousness cannot work.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And if you want a short code mnemonic for why those theories of consciousness cannot be right, it is those theories of consciousness treat the brain as a computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So they have encoding, but they don't have decoding.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so they can't get consciousness has decoded meaning.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so a theory which only has encoding, but no decoding can't get decoded meaning.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And you can divide that set.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You can say the higher order computing about an object B
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: is done by process P4B, and that is done by certain neurons which we've identified called N4B and so on and so forth.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so there we are, we've made great progress in cognitive science, understanding how the brain works.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And now we propose a theory of consciousness.

text: So what form would that theory take?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Inside the brain is not known which are neurons N3B.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: There might be any neurons.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, and the information to decode
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: N3B as the process P3B doesn't exist inside the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I'll just restate the incompleteness theorem.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The physical events inside a computer don't define what it computes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The proposal here is that the extra something is an analog model of reality.

text: And that an analog model is different from what goes on in digital computers or neural computers.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So what's an analog model?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Approach this by examples.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: A toy car is an analog model of a real car.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or a map is an analog model of a piece of terrain.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Or a photograph is an analog model of some scene.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I claim we try and encapsulate this in definition of what is an analog model.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: A model M is an analog model of some physical situation P if
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: M has the same topology as P. In other words, if the situation P is donut shaped, then M is donut shaped.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And there's some kind of point to point correspondence between the physical situation P and the model M. So a point in the model is a function of a point in the physical thing.

text: And it preserves neighborhoods.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And it preserves spatial binding.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So there are things in the analog model, which are like borders, for instance, borders on a map, which are also borders in the real situation.
